Description 1:
A 62-year-old male patient, an ex-smoker with a 30-pack-year history, presented with persistent dry cough and exertional dyspnea. He described the cough as hacking and rated his chest discomfort at 4/10 in intensity. The dyspnea was notably worse during physical activities, and he reported a baseline oxygen saturation level of 92% on room air. Notably, the patient has been using home oxygen therapy at a flow rate of 5 L/min. Physical examination revealed coarse crackles in bilateral lung fields. The patient's occupational history included long-term exposure to industrial fumes. Pulmonary function tests indicated a restrictive pattern. The presence of humidification-related symptom, in the context of an oxygen flow rate > 4 L/min, poses a diagnostic challenge in this case.

Description 2:
A 45-year-old female patient, with a known medical history of systemic sclerosis, presented with a chief complaint of worsening dyspnea at rest and a non-productive cough. The dyspnea was severe, with the patient rating it at 8/10 in intensity. She reported a significant reduction in her exercise tolerance over the past two months. Additionally, the patient noted a new onset of fingertip ulcers and Raynaud's phenomenon. Physical examination revealed bibasilar crackles and evidence of advanced skin tightening. High-resolution computed tomography of the chest showed findings consistent with interstitial lung disease. Of note, the patient's home oxygen requirement was 6 L/min, and she reported a subjective feeling of "dryness" during inhalation. The presence of humidification-related symptom, in the context of systemic sclerosis and an oxygen flow rate > 4 L/min, further complicates the diagnostic assessment in this case.

Description 3:
A 55-year-old male patient, who worked as a metal fitter, presented with a chronic dry cough and mild dyspnea during strenuous activities. He described the cough as persistent and rated his chest discomfort at 3/10 in intensity. The patient had a remote history of asbestos exposure in his occupation. Physical examination revealed digital clubbing and fine, inspiratory crackles in the lower lung zones. Pulmonary function tests showed a restrictive pattern, with a reduced diffusion capacity. High-resolution computed tomography of the chest demonstrated interstitial lung abnormalities. Notably, the patient's oxygen supplementation at home was at a flow rate of 5 L/min. He reported a sensation of airway dryness, especially during exertion. The presence of humidification-related symptom, in the setting of occupational asbestos exposure and an oxygen flow rate > 4 L/min, adds complexity to the diagnostic considerations for this patient.
